description.narrative: Consumer Unity and Trust Society (CUTS) International and its local partners have been implementing the project “Promoting Agriculture Climate change and Trade in EAC Region (PACT EAC)” with support from Sida since November 2011 and has now applied for a continuation of the Project from 2015-2019, with an addition of putting the nexus of climate Change, trade and food security in relation to agroindustry and agro value addition. The project originally emerged out of the need in EAC region to find solutions to the challenges of climate change that has manifested in the frequent droughts and posing food insecurity challenges. In addition, the EAC region has limited capacity related to multilateral trade negotiations and limited ability to involve grassroot stakeholders, and thereby limited knowledge about the interests and needs of key poor stakeholders. At the end of the first incarnation of the project, stakeholder consultations made it clear that a there was a high demand for a continuation with a focus on agricultural value addition. Furthermore, the external evaluation which was conducted during 2014 recommended a continuation of the project in order to capture and enhance the positive progress during the first project period. The aim of PACT EAC2 is to continue to build capacity of EAC Region to better understand and effectively use climate change, trade and food security linkages to agro industry, as well as improve the capacities of the EAC countries in WTO and UNFCCC discussions and negotiations. The overall objective is to promote climate-friendly and trade-driven agro-value-addition in the EAC to reduce poverty and improve food security through holistic national, regional and multilateral policies and agreements dealing with trade, climate change and agriculture. The project also aims to increase EAC’s ability to influence multilateral trade and climate negotiations as well as to enhance the linkages between policymakers and grassroot stakeholders in the EAC region.

Consumer Unity and Trust Society (CUTS) International och dess lokala partner har genomfört projektet “Promoting Agriculture Climate change and Trade in EAC Region (PACT EAC)” med stöd från Sida sedan november 2011 och har nu lämnat in en ansökan om en förlängning av projektet från 2015-2019, med fokus på policys inom jordbruksindustri och jordbruksförädling och att i förhållande till detta belysa kopplingar mellan klimatförändringar, handel och en tryggad livsmedelsförsörjning. Projektet uppstod ur ett behov som EAC-regionen har att finna lösningar på de utmaningar som klimatförändringar ställer regionen inför, t.ex. en livsmedelsförsörjning som påverkats av återkommande torka. Dessutom har EAC-regionen begränsad kapacitet att delta i multilaterala handelsförhandlingar och begränsad förmåga att i dessa engagera regionens gräsrötter, och därmed begränsad kunskap om fattigas intressen och behov. I slutet av det första projektet genomfördes en konsultation med projektets intressenter och då framkom att det fanns en stor efterfrågan på ett fortsättningsprojekt, och då med fokus på jordbruksförädling. Den externa utvärderingen som genomfördes 2014 rekommenderade att projektet förlängs med en ytterligare projektperiod för att fånga upp och förstärka de positiva resultat som uppnåtts under den första projektperioden. Syftet med PACT EAC2 är att fortsätta att bygga upp kapaciteten hos EAC regionen för att bättre förstå och använda kopplingar mellan klimatförändringar, handel och livsmedelsförsörjning i relation till jordbruksförädling, samt förbättra kapaciteten hos EAC-länderna i WTO och UNFCCC-förhandlingar. Det övergripande målet är att främja klimatvänlig och handelsdriven jordbruksförädling i EAC regionen för att minska fattigdom och förbättra livsmedelsförsörjningen genom holistiska nationella, regionala och multilaterala strategier och i avtal på handels-, klimat- och jordbruksområdet. Projektet syftar också till att öka EAC:s förmåga att påverka multilaterala handels- och klimatförhandlingar samt att förbättra kopplingen mellan politiska beslutsfattare och gräsrötter i EAC-regionen.

The intervention intended to contribute to agro-industrial policy development in the EAC countries to be conscious of challenges related to climate change, food security, and trade. The purpose was to build capacities of East African stakeholders for climate-aware, trade-driven and food security-enhancing agro-processing in the region. The project "Promoting Agriculture, Climate and Trade linkages in the East African Community - Phase 2" (PACT EAC2) had three specific objectives. 1. Increase knowledge and capacity of national and regional stakeholders on agro-value addition to contribute to formulation and implementation of holistic policies re climate change, food security and trade 2. Increase knowledge and capacity to negotiate in the WTO and UNFCCC on issues related to agro-value addition 3. Improve coordination between and across stakeholders at national, regional and multilateral levels for holistic approaches and regular information sharing. CUTS International Geneva was implementing the project together with local partners such as CUTS International Nairobi (national activities in Kenya, coordinate regional activities in EAC and facilitate for other national partners), EAC secretariat as regional partner and national country partners include Burundi: Action, Développement et Intégration Régionale (ADIR), Rwanda: ACORD Rwanda, Tanzania: Economic and Social Research Foundation (ESRF), Uganda: Southern and Eastern African Trade, Information and Negotiations Institute (SEATINI).

description.narrative: The purpose was to build capacities of East African stakeholders to promote climate-aware, trade-driven and food security-enhancing agro-processing policies in the region. The project brought together, informed, trained and moved to advocacy action hundreds of stakeholders from the government, businesses, civil society, media, academia and farming communities in five EAC countries Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Rwanda and Burundi. The project contributed to increased knowledge and capacity of national and regional stakeholders on agro-value addition to contribute to formulation and implementation of holistic policies re climate change, food security and trade. By the end of the project 98% of 1274 responding stakeholders had better understanding how agro-processing can be more trade-driven, climate friendly and food security enhancing in the EAC region. A general better understanding on the linkages for 297 policy-makers, 130 agro-producers, and 154 agro-businesses and over 623 000 East African readers have been reached through the media. The project has involved at least 192 policy makers in various advocacy campaigns, whose influence can now be tracked in 10 policy efforts by East African governments to enhance policy synergies across climate change, trade, food security and agro-industry. At the national level, in Burundi, the project, through ADIR, supported drafting "Burundi's National Industrialization Policy" and a plan for finalising the policy was adopted in 2018. In Rwanda CUTS supported the creation of the "National Agro-Processing Forum" to convey agro-processors’ perspectives into Rwanda's industrial policy implementation machinery. In Kenya, CUTS Nairobi contributed to finalising the "Buy Kenya, Build Kenya Strategy", which now integrates elements of trade, climate and food security. In Tanzania the review by "Tanzania’s Sustainable Industrial Development Policy", the local partner ESRF has been advocating for starting the review process. In Uganda, the local partner SEATINI supported the development of the "National Industrial Development Policy" and "Ugandan Climate Change Bill". At the regional level CUTS has been involved to develop trade-related position papers: (i) compliance with standards and certification; (ii) tackling Non-Tariff Barriers; (iii) Trade facilitation; (iv) Buy East Africa, Build East Africa; (v) Institutional Frameworks; (vi) Harnessing Digitalisation. Similarly, recommended climate-related provisions related to: (i) Making it a priority cross-cutting area; (ii) Upscaling Green Investments; (iii) Mobilising Climate Finance; (iv) Role of private sector organisations; and (v) Private sector awareness and involvement. Moreover, CUTS has been involved in the development of the "EAC Regional Private Sector Strategy". At the global level, the project also supported increased knowledge and capacity to negotiate in the WTO and UNFCCC on issues related to agro-value addition. Among the policy makers and UNFCCC negotiators trained, 95% reported having better capacities to coherently take into account climate, trade and food security concerns into agro-processing-related policy work. Regarding climate and trade negotiators a large majority (88%) reported being better able to identify and represent their country’s interests as negotiators. The project championed at least three East African submissions to UNFCCC on the Koronivia Joint Work on Agriculture, and identified at least three WTO submissions by EAC countries addressing relevant aspects of sustainable agro-processing development. Finally the project contributed to improved coordination between and across stakeholders at national, regional and multilateral levels for holistic approaches and regular information sharing. An important part of the project has been to ensure coordinated policies at national, regional and global levels. A major result is that stakeholders interact more regularly with PACT EAC2 completion in September 2019, the project had become a major forum for convergence where cross-issue experience-sharing had fostered pluri-disciplinary thinking across agro-processing, climate change, trade and food security. Indeed, 828 stakeholders (74%) reported having recently maintained more regular interactions with professionals from other issue areas. On average, 95% of them thought project meetings were good opportunities in this regard.
